msIdentifier.repository: Gonville and Caius College, Lower Library
msIdentifier.idno: Cambridge, Gonville and Caius College, MS 401/623

summary.seg: This manuscript, like many others included in the Curious Cures in Cambridge Libraries project was once owned or used by Roger Marchall (c. 1417-1477) Rogerus Marshall (c. 1417-1477) , a doctor and physician to King Edward IV. Marchall added titles to some of the treatises in the volume. Marchall's ownership or use of manuscripts is very well-attested, with forty-five surviving books (including this one) bearing evidence to connect him to them in some way; six others may have been his or accessed by him, and a further twelve are recorded but not traced. This volume does not have Marchall's signature, or a table of contents in his hand, which are both features found in many of the other books he owned and used, but Marchall's distinctive hand is evident in the titles added in the upper margins of pp. 63 ('Passionarius platearii'), 96 ('Modus medendi Ricardi medici probatissimi'), and 167 ('Glosa platearii super antidotarium Nicholai').

As described by Linda Voigts, the present manuscript is one of eighteen (possibly nineteen) manuscripts at Gonville and Caius College that may be linked to Marchall, and which were probably donated by him to Gonville Hall (as Gonville and Caius then was); King's College and Peterhouse, where the study of medicine was also supported, received gifts of books from him too. Thirteen manuscripts owned or used by Marchall (and another with possible Marchall connections) have been digitised, catalogued and conserved as part of the Curious Cures in Cambridge Libraries project:
Cambridge, Gonville and Caius College, MS 59/153 (Voigts 1995, no. 2)
Cambridge, Gonville and Caius College, MS 98/50 (Voigts 1995, no. 4)
Cambridge, Gonville and Caius College, MS 105/57 (Voigts 1995, no. 5)
Cambridge, Gonville and Caius College, MS 159/209 (Voigts 1995, no. 9)
Cambridge, Gonville and Caius College, MS 178/211 (Voigts 1995, no. 10)
Cambridge, Gonville and Caius College, MS 181/214 (Voigts 1995, no. 11)
Cambridge, Gonville and Caius College, MS 345/620 (Voigts 1995, no. 12)
Cambridge, Gonville and Caius College, MS 373/593 (Voigts 1995, no. 13)
Cambridge, Gonville and Caius College, MS 379/599 (Voigts 1995, no. 14)
Cambridge, Gonville and Caius College, MS 401/623 (Voigts 1995, no. 16)
Cambridge, Peterhouse, MS 95 (Voigts 1995, no. 24)
Cambridge, Peterhouse, MS 222 (Voigts 1995, no. 28)
Cambridge, Trinity College, MS O.8.31 (Voigts 1995, no. 29)
Cambridge, University Library, MS Add. 9213 (possible Marchall connections) (Voigts 1995, no. 48)

Dr Sarah Gilbert
Project Cataloguer for the Curious Cures Project
Cambridge University Library

References: See L. Voigts, 'A doctor and his books: the manuscripts of Roger Marchall (d. 1477)', in R. Beadle and A. J. Piper (eds.), New science out of old books: studies in manuscripts and early printed books in honour of A.I. Doyle (Aldershot, 1995) pp. 249-314

supportDesc.support: A composite manuscript, all Parts of parchment and a single paper endleaf at each end of the volume.

foliation.note: Paginated in ink in the upper outer corner of each recto and verso. The paper endleaves are unpaginated in the manuscript; the designations in square brackets [i-ii] and [iii-iv] were assigned in 2023 by the Curious Cures project in the preparation of the online catalogue record for this item.

supportDesc.collation:
This is a composite volume with three Parts, the first Part, unusually, is divided into two sub-Parts, the first sub-Part at the opening of the volume, and the second sub-Part as the penultimate item in the volume, so the composite structure can be understood as: Part 1, Part 2, Part 1, Part 3. The quires are arranged as follows:
Quire 18 (pp. 1-16)
Quire 2one (1 leaf remains; pp. 17-18) |
Quire 34 (pp. 19-26)
Quires 4-58 (pp. 27-58)
Quire 62 (pp. 59-62)
Quire 78 (pp. 63-78)
Quire 84 (pp. 79-86)
Quire 96 (pp. 87-98)
Quires 10-114 (pp. 99-114)
Quires 12-138 (pp. 115-146)
Quire 144 (pp. 147-154)
Quire 156 (pp. 155-166)
Quires 16-188 (pp. 167-214) |
Quire 194 (pp. 215-222) |
Quire 20one (1 leaf remains; pp. 223-224)
18 2one (1 leaf remains) | 34 4-58 62 78 84 96 10-114 12-138 144 156 16-188 | 194 | 20one (1 leaf remains)
Alphanumeric medieval leaf signatures in ink in the lower outer corner of the rectos in the first half of each quire. This signature sequence begins at p. 17, which has the designation 'k i', and continues throughout the volume ending with z, the typical medieval 'con' abbreviation, and three dots arranged in an inverted triangle for the final three quires according to the sequence.
Late-19th or early-20th century quire sequence in pencil in the lower outer corner of the first recto in a quire; the first two quires are unmarked. This quire sequence begins at p. 19, which is designated as '1', and the sequence continues to '16' on p. 199; the two remaining subsequent quires are designated 'c' (p. 215) and 'd' (p. 223) in this sequence.

binding.p: Early-17th century binding. Fully bound in leather over paste- or millboards with matching decoration in blind to left and right covers. Covers are decorated with two concentric quadruple-fillet frames, the outermost frame set at the perimeter of the boards, the innermost frame inset by c. 20 mm; the frames are connected at their adjacent corners with a quadruple-fillet. Five raised bands on the spine, the upper and lower perimeters of each compartment decorated with a quadruple fillet. Russia leather labels stained black in two compartments with titles tooled in gold: TRACTATUS MEDICI and RIC. DE BARO PLATERARII &c.. Two printed paper labels fixed to the spine with an adhesive, '623' printed in red, and '401' printed in black - these numbers form the current shelfmark of the volume. Damage to upper spine opening, head band torn away; lower spine opening is capped and no tail band is visible. Decorative roll of an acanthus set in an arch along the turn ins and the head, fore, and tail edges of the cover.

Paper pastedowns over the turn ins. One paper endleaf at each end of the volume (ff. [i] and [ii]). The left pastedown contains a Gonville and Caius bookplate with the numbers '623' and '401' written in ink, and the note 975. Pr. lat in ink in a corner of the plate.

provenance.p: Titles to medical works in the hand of Roger Marchall (c. 1417-1477) Rogerus Marshall -1477 on pp. 63, 96, 167. Marchall was a physician who donated several medical manuscripts to Gonville and Caius and who seems to have consulted (and annotated) many of the medical manuscripts belonging to various Cambridge College Libraries during his lifetime. For more information see L. Voigts, 'A Doctor And His Books'.

The name 'Humfridus Bohun' (Humphrey Bohun) appears in the outer margin of p. 201 in light brown ink in a hand of early-modern aspect. This Humphrey Bohun is probably the Humphrey Bohun Humphrey Bohun (b. c. 1534 - d. c. 1632) who matriculated at St John's College in 1552 and was a Fellow of Gonville and Caius College c. 1566-1567. There are several other minor pen trials and scribbles in Bohun's hand throughout the volume. Venn:ACAD BHN552H

history.acquisition: No acquisition information recorded by the College, but probably given to the College by either Marchall (before 1477) or Bohun (probably before 1567).

recordHist.source: This catalogue entry draws on M. R. James, A Descriptive Catalogue of the Manuscripts in the Library of Gonville and Caius College, 2. vols (Cambridge, 1908) and unpublished notes on Cambridge medical manuscripts by Dr Debby Banham.

availability.p: Visitors to Gonville and Caius College who wish to consult Lower Library material are required to apply to the Library in advance of their visit. For information on eligibility and admission procedures see: Gonville and Caius College: Library Information.

custEvent.p: Probably the work recorded as no. 81 Medicina Platearii (p. 103) in the Ecloga Oxonio-Cantabrigiensis by Thomas James (1600). There is an '81' in brown ink in the upper margin of p. 1.
No. 975 in Bernard, Catalogi librorum manuscriptorum Angliæ et Hiberniæ (c. 1697). The reference number 975 is recorded in ink on the bookplate on the left pastedown.

monogr.title: Anglo-Norman medicine. - Vol.1: Roger Frugard's "Chirurgia"; "Practica Brevis" of Platearius

analytic.title: A doctor and his books: the manuscripts of Roger Marchall (d. 1477)

monogr.title: New science out of old books: studies in manuscripts and early printed books in honour of A.I. Doyle

msIdentifier.idno: Cambridge, Gonville and Caius College, MS 401/623, pp. 1-18 and pp. 215-222

msItem.title: Practica (Rogerina maior)
msItem.author: Rogerius de Baron (attrib.)
msItem.incipit: 1 sis reumaticis non debet fieri flebotomia sicut intellige in apparentibus sanis

note.p: This Part of the manuscript has been broken into two sections, one at the beginning of the manuscript (pp. 1-18) and one towards the end (pp. 215-222), but both sections are by the same scribe and are derived from the same original manuscript.
Occasional marginal annotations expanding on the content of the text in a contemporary hand.

supportDesc.collation:
This Part is comprised of material from 3 quires. One leaf remains of Quire 2:
Quire 18 (pp. 1-16)
Quire 2one (1 leaf remains; pp. 17-18) +
Quire 194 (pp. 215-222)
supportDesc.condition: Sewn repair to lower margin of pp. 9-10. Lower margin of pp. 11-12 trimmed away. Two holes in pp. 15-16.

p.seg: Ruled in light brown ink, frame and lines. Ruled in two-column format, typically 42 lines to the column, and written below top line.

handNote.p: Written in a 13th century textualis libraria.

decoNote.p: Empty spaces for minor initials throughout this Part of the manuscript. No other notable decoration.

origin.origDate: This Part was copied in the 13th century.
origin.origPlace: This Part was copied in England.

msIdentifier.idno: Cambridge, Gonville and Caius College, MS 401/623, pp. 19-214

msItem.title: Practica (Rogerina maior) (Latin)
msItem.author: Rogerius de Baron (attrib.)
msItem.incipit: 19 tenuat splenem. Item. De tercio in tercium affer diasone acuatum cum lapide lazuli.
msItem.note: Additional nedical recipes in the lower margins of most leaves.

msItem.title: Rogerina minor (Latin)
msItem.author: Rogerius de Baron (attrib.)
msItem.incipit: 54 Cum artis medicine due sint partes
msItem.explicit: 62 in quo mulier solet habere menstrua sua
msItem.finalRubric: 62 Explicit minor summa magistri R. de baro
msItem.note: Additional medical recipes in the lower margins of most leaves.

msItem.title: Practica breuis
msItem.author: Joannes Platearius (fl. c. 1090-1120)
msItem.explicit: 96 puluis inde factus cum licinio fistule immittatur.
msItem.note: Title in Roger Marchall's hand in the upper margin of p. 63: 'Passionarius Platearii'.

msItem.title: De modo medendi
msItem.author: Gerard of Montpellier / Gerard of Cremona
msItem.incipit: 96 Cum omnis ars ex suo fine laudabilis existat
msItem.explicit: 113 et hec de medicinis laxatiuis sufficiant
msItem.note: Title in Roger Marchall's hand in the upper margin of p. 96: 'Modus medendi Ricardi medici probatissimi'.

msItem.title: De repressiuis
msItem.author: Ricardus Anglicus
msItem.explicit: 114 prope radicem in stipite facto foramina cum cerebello
msItem.note: Follows the Summa de laxatiuis of Gerard of Montpellier.

msItem.title: De simplicibus medicinae ('Circa instans') [Latin]
msItem.author: Mattheus Platearius (d. c. 1161) (attrib.)
msItem.incipit: 115 Circa instans negotium in simplicibus medicinis nostrum uersatur propositum
msItem.note: The recension of this text in Gonville and Caius MS 401/623 is closes to the version in Paris, Bibliothèque nationale de France, MS lat. 14025, ff. 103ra-125rb. The first entry after the prologue begins on p. 115: Aloe est calida et sicca complexionis in secundo gradu

msItem.title: Treatise on urine
msItem.incipit: 152 Et quia corruptum est corrumpit urinam . Uirum et liuorem indicat .
msItem.explicit: 153 quia lapis paruus non multum opilat
msItem.note: Additions medical annotations in the lower margins.

msItem.title: Medical recipes, perhaps extracts from the Antidotarium magnum
msItem.incipit: 154 De oximel iuliani . Oximel iuliani optimum arteticis et podagricis et mirabiliter
msItem.explicit: 166 sanitatem mentis et corporis accipere mereatur qui uiuis et r. d.
msItem.finalRubric: 166 finiunt hic exceptiones et meliores Receptiones antidotarii maioris

msItem.title: Medical recipe
msItem.note: In the lower margin of p. 166 in a ?15th century hand.

msItem.title: Commentary on the Antidotarium Nicolai
msItem.author: Mattheus Platearius (d. c. 1161)
msItem.incipit: 167 Liber iste quem in presentiarum legendum assumpsimus ex multorum antidotis est compilatus
msItem.explicit: 200 Datur in sero cum calida in modum castanee . per .ii. an s'.
msItem.note: Title added by Roger Marchall in the upper margin of p. 167: 'Glosa platearii super antidotarium Nicholai'.

msItem.title: Three medical recipes
msItem.note: The first recipe in perhaps the main text hand, the second and third recipes in a different hand of a similar or slightly later date.
The text is similar to Rome, Biblioteca Apostolica Vaticana, MS Pal. lat. 4422, ff. 7r-9r (eTK 0495J).

msItem.title: De medicamentis
msItem.incipit: 201 Humores purgantia generaliter et naturaliter ostensuri ; a flegmagogis nostre orationi non inmerito censuimus dare principiam.

catchwords.seg: Catchwords occasionally found in the lower inner corner of the last verso of each quire, e.g., p. 106.

supportDesc.condition: The parchment in this part is generally in good condition. Some leaves are stained and have minor liquid damage. Some leaves have ?medieval sewn repairs to slits and holes in the parchment.

p.seg: Ruled in leadpoint, frame and lines. Ruled in double-column format, typically 75 lines to the column and written below top line.

handNote.p: The main text is copied in an extremely small form of textualis libraria sometimes known as pearl script; this script was particularly popular in western Europe in the 13th century.
There are annotations in the margins of this Part by at least two ?13th century scribes whose marginal notes are written in various forms of textualis currens.

decoNote.p: Flourished initials with red grounds and blue flourishing or the reverse at the major and minor divisions of the text.
Most texts have rubricated (red only) incipits, explicits, and section headings.

origin.origDate: This part of the manuscript was copied in the 13th century.

msIdentifier.idno: Cambridge, Gonville and Caius College, MS 401/623, pp. 223-224

msItem.title: Medical treatise
msItem.incipit: 223 His odores bonai apponantur frigida aspergantur sorbitiones et fricationes pectoris
msItem.explicit: 223 proportionaliter et utatur ... . et nec est solus et nec curata et conseruata

msItem.author: Constantinus Africanus
msItem.title: Extract from the Viaticum (Book 7, ch. 17)
msItem.incipit: 224 Morphea est macula in cute ex corruptione nutrimenti
msItem.explicit: 224 Uel aliud accipe fenum humidum . et sub ea quinque uel iiiior carbones

supportDesc.condition: Minor stains on leaf. Text on verso is rubbed and partially clouded by adhesive residue.

p.seg: Page 223 is ruled in single-column format. Frame ruled in leadpoint, now very faint, lines ruled blind, pricking visible in outer margin. 45 lines of text, written above top line.
Page 224 is ruled in double-column format. Frame ruled in leadpoint, now very faint, lines ruled blind, pricking visible in outer margin. 45 lines of text, written above top line.

handNote.p: Page 223 is written in a neat protogothic minuscule of the 12th century.
Page 224 is written in a transitional textualis minuscule of the late 12th or early 13th century that retains protogothic features.

decoNote.p: There are no decorative features in this Part of the manuscript.

binding.p: This leaf (pp. 223-224) was probably once used as a pastedown in a former binding. The leaf has adhesive residue on the verso in a typical pastedown-and-turn-in pattern and has small holes in the centre of the outer margin that may have been caused by a metal fastening fixed to the old binding.

origin.origDate: The text on the recto of this leaf (p. 223) was written in the 12th century.

change.persName: Dr Sarah Gilbert, Project Cataloguer, Curious Cures in Cambridge Libraries Project
